title: Georgia House - Day 3 (2026-01-10)
summary:
Overview:
This Georgia House session on January 10, 2026 featured a routine opening, with prayer, the pledge of allegiance, and the introduction of the guest chaplain. No substantive legislative actions were detected in the transcript.

Key Actions: 
None detected.

Bills Introduced (First Reading):
None detected.

Notable Moments:
- The guest chaplain, Dr. Justin Norles, gave a sermon on biblical principles of leadership, emphasizing that leaders are called by God to serve others.
- The House Speaker thanked the chaplain and his wife for their visit.

Votes:
None detected.

Attendance:
The session began with a roll call to establish quorum.

Adjournment:
The transcript does not indicate when the session was adjourned or when the next session will be.

you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you This is Claire. How about Ring that Bill? We're going to have the morning roll call. All members present will please vote green to signify their presence in the chamber. And Mr. Clerk, will you unlock the machines? Have all members voted? Have all members voted? If so, the clerk will lock the machines. Doorkypers, will you please close those doors and keep them closed? As is our custom, we will begin our day with Scripture reading and prayer by the chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Had a great visit with the chaplain and his wife this morning, both very fine people, so at this point in time, I'll let you learn a little more about them. And they'll be introduced by the gentleman from the 144th House District, Representative Dale Washman. Representative Washman. Well, thank you very much, Mr. Speaker. Ladies and gentlemen, the House is a great privilege for me today to introduce to you as our chaplain of the day, Dr. Justin Norles. And Dr. Norles is here with us with his wife Cassie, who's not over here next to my wife Donna, who you know. And Dr. Norles and Cassie have four children. Dr. Norles is the teaching pastor at Inglocide Baptist Church, where Donna and I have been active for many years. It is a large church in central Georgia. He is the teaching pastor there. He has a bachelor's degree from Mississippi College, a master of divinity from Beeson Divinity School at Sanford University, a master of theology from Duke Divinity School, and a PhD from Spurgeon's College in London, England. Donna and I have been members, active members. It angles I have for many years. And Dr. Norles has been with us for ten years. I'm a lifelong Baptist, and I've heard a lot of good teaching and preaching as many of you have. But I will tell you that I have been very blessed by the teaching and the preaching of Dr. Justin Norles. And I look forward to hearing him today. Ladies and gentlemen, it's Donna for me to present to you our chaplain of the day, Dr. Justin Norles. Good ahead, yours. Well, thank you, Mr. Speaker, for the invitation to be here today. And to really enjoy and to privilege. And thank you all for having me. I want to say thanks, first of all, to you and for all that you do. I'm really grateful for your willingness to serve our state and to put in all the work, to do that well in the way that you do. And obviously, this is a room full of leaders. You obviously have a leadership role. I'm here within this body. And I would imagine many of you have leadership roles outside this body. Whether that's in your family or your church or community, or places of work. And so I want to share some few thoughts this morning on leadership. And there are thoughts that come from the biblical book of Psalms. Specifically, Psalm 78, the end of that chapter. And you're the end of Psalm 78. It talks some about King David. David was a king of Israel. Perhaps the best known, that king of Israel. David was not a perfect king. He was not a perfect leader. In fact, maybe one of the best known stories about David is about one of his failures. So he was not a perfect leader. But he was a good leader. And there are some important lessons that we can learn from his life. So in Psalm 78, sorry, in verse 70, it says, God chose David, his servants, and took him from the sheepfolds. From following the nursing news, he brought him to shepherd Jacob, his people, Israel, his inheritance. As you notice, it says that God chose David to serve as a leader. As a sovereignty, he chose the person that he wanted to be in that position of leadership at that time. Of course, first, David was a shepherd. The Lord used that time to prepare him for the role that God was going to use him as a king. David shepherded sheep before he shepherded people. It was a way of God preparing him. And then at just the right time, God put him in that position of leadership over the nation. It reminds me of what the Bible says in Romans 13, where it says, let every person be subject to the governing authorities for there is no authority except from God. And those that exist have been instituted by God. I think David's example in Romans 13 teach us that it's not a coincidence that you are in this position of leadership at this particular time. The Lord has appointed this governing body for this time to serve other people by promoting what is truly good and just. It also tells us that God is very much involved, that he has plans for the world and for the people that he's created. And one of the ways that God provides for societies is through government leaders that are called to serve just like you. But you also notice it says that David was called for what purpose to shepherd people. What does a shepherd do? Well, of course, provide some overall leadership and he does that largely by providing and protecting by doing what is good for the sheep. But genuinely caring for them. I think all of that then should really give us a sense of purpose related to our leadership and help us see the significant responsibility that comes with it. It keeps us aware that our leadership is not fundamentally about ourselves. It is not a means of self promotion. It's not self serving. Our leadership is part of something bigger. We are put in place by God to serve others, to leverage our leadership for the good of others. He reminds me of another shepherd in the Bible, the good shepherd, Jesus. I love what he says in John 10 when he made clear that he had all authority in heaven and on earth. And what did he choose to do with his authority? John 10, he tells us that he chose to lay down his life for his people. Like a good shepherd giving his life for his sheep. On another occasion, he said that he didn't come to be served but to serve. God himself, King of kings, Lord of lords, God in the flesh saying he came to serve. And to give his life as a ransom for many that we might have eternal life. His example teaches us that we are meant to leverage our leadership for the good of others, to lay down our lives for the good of those that we lead. And so here's the lesson this morning that I want to see here from Scripture. Simply that those of us in leadership are put there by God to serve others for their good. We join me as we pray. Our Father in heaven, I thank you for your provision through the leaders in this room. And I pray that you would incline their hearts toward you. Fill them with your wisdom that they might lead in a way that is consistent with your character and your commands and is good for others. But I thank you that your grace is sufficient for all of us to do what you have called us to do. The grace that has been expressed ultimately through the death and resurrection of your son Jesus. And it's in his name that I pray. Amen. You know what you join me as we say the pledge. I pledge allegiance to the plight of the United States of America and to the Republic of which it stands, the One Nation under God, indivisible with liberty and justice for all. Excellent. The Lord, keepers, you may unlock the doors, members. You may greet the chaplain in the south any room. If you would like to greet the men, have a photo. Chaplain, pastor, thank you for those words. They are very meaningful. And thank you for both of you for being here today with us. We look forward to having you back. Great. Thank you. Thank you. Only 38 more days. We're in good place. Three-second readers. We have no standing committee reports. Correct, Ms. Clerk? Mr. Clerk, Madam Clerk. Members in any room, I'll ask, if you all come to the floor, take your seats, we'll come to order. All members, we have some important work to do here. We have some members that have served this house in this state with distinction we're going to hear from. So I'll ask all members, please take your seats and let me have your attention. All members. Thank you members. All members, please take your seats. You know it's always a bittersweet time in this family of house members over the years and one of our members. You know a lot of times it's the end of the session when we do this and hear from a house member that may decide not to come back or offer themselves for a real election. This time we have one of our members that's moving on a little earlier. This gentleman represented Barry Fleming and served this house with distinction. He has served the people of Georgia and his district with distinction and with effectiveness. Barry's our dear friend who I respect greatly and admire. He's taken the skill set to another place he can serve the people of his district and he'll tell us about that. I'm going to allow him to do this. Representative Fleming, I'd like for you to come down now and be recognized by a special morning order. Let us know what's going on in your life. Representative Barry Fleming. Thank you, Miss Speaker. And I do mean thank you, Mr. Speaker. Every time you come to this well and I'd have for about 21 years or so we say thank you, Mr. Speaker. And for letting us stand here because we have to have his permission to do that. And not only do I say thank you, Mr. Speaker, but thank you also because I don't think even those of us so close to this job realize how much it takes out of a person to serve in the role as a man behind me does. Man, you and I both know the the the pools on us. But when you step up and become Speaker of this house, not only you probably one of the most important man obviously in this state, but the commitment it takes from your your time and your family and you don't get to see your grandkids like you want to and you missed stuff. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for what you do for us. Thank you. You may be seated. You may be seated. Me too, is it going to be that long? Gotta get used to that, I think. About 21 years ago when I first got elected to this house, then Governor Perdue had to make his first judicial appointment in the state and in an opening came in my district and he and I talked about that and he was very gracious to give me the opportunity to be a spirit court judge, but I did not think it was the right time for me. So I um I said no and I didn't know if that opportunity would ever come along again. Uh well, lo and behold it has and I am extremely thankful to Governor Kemp for allowing me this afternoon to raise my hand and move from the legislative branch of government over to the judicial branch of government where I think most law students at some point they they wonder if they will ever get to serve as a judge one day and I didn't know if I would, but I am very thankful for to him for giving me that opportunity. I also want to say how thankful I am to our Governor for the leadership, particularly it probably one of the toughest times I know in my lifetime I have ever seen a Governor have to serve during COVID. We all know how it turned our lives upside down and how difficult some of the decisions we had to make right here on this floor work. Can you imagine being the chief executive of the state and having to deal with that and I thank him profusely. I know in my behalf and I'm sure yours too for being the leader that he was particularly doing that time period. Thank you Governor. As I as I pause, obviously and I look out here on the floor, I see so many friends on both sides of the aisle. I see Mary Margaret over there. I see my Prince right there. There is Sheila and of course my dog Dmitrius and I do mean dog, DAWG dog. Go dogs. One of the greatest things about coming down to this place is particularly for us who have to come from far away and get a place to stay down here is this whole idea of getting a roommate which I've been able to do. You know we did that in college many of us and that was fun. You really got to know folks when you were roommate and then I got to do it again after undergraduate. I went to DC and worked for a congressman and I had a roommate up there. My college roommate, my attorney brother Steve Fowler, still my best friend, Patrick Crusoe, one of my roommates up in Connecticut. He's now a judge. Just became a judge up there in Connecticut. Here my roommate was representative Kelly and we tried to figure it out. I think it's been eight years. He's put up with me and I want to say thank you for that. You know when you leave this place even though if you get to move on to an opportunity like me you still worry about what goes on behind after you leave and many of you, one of the joys of serving here is to get to help many of you as an attorney. Perfect your legislation, get the wording right. It's one of the benefits and of service that we get from my profession. I'll tell you a little secret. If you need somebody smart, go to Kelly. I mean he's actually a smarter lawyer than I am but don't tell him I don't want him to get the big head. Seeing those young people though that are here to follow us is one of the things that gives you comfort when you move on and I know I see representative gamble back there. You know when I was elected to this place in 20 and 002 I started going to the prayer call. It's that is on Wednesday mornings and when I first started it was a guy named Tom Rice from Gwinnett County and then Timmy Barr took it over after he retired and then representative gamble is doing it now that prayer call because I would greatly encourage you it's right in the center of the week on Wednesday if you want to get your life centered down here and keep your head on straight go to that prayer call because I appreciate him doing that. I call him a young person he's got three three kids but I don't know they keep getting younger it seems like dawn down here these young people. I'm so thankful to have had a chance to be just a small part of the rich history of this house sometimes some of us will say you know somebody ought to write this stuff down some of the things that occurs down here maybe I will one day but the way we only know some of the history is by telling each other about things that we've experienced and I have so enjoyed my my time down here listening to some of the things that have happened the rich history of this house and I'll tell you a couple of them one of my saw personally and one of my heard about and the first one I heard from got named Larry Walker who was majority of this house for a number of years his son centered to Walker now serves across the aisle over there but both stories center around that man we call the speaker of the house the term speaker was defined for about 30 years down here by a guy named Tom Murphy Thomas be Murphy long as serving speaker of the house when he served down here and like him or disagree with him he was the speaker governor's came and went but the speaker was always here the story is is that he was elected as a young man to this house in 1960 and he came down here and was a lawyer from over in West Georgia I think Tyler Paul Smith has most of his district he was from Bremen Georgia and in his first term he got behind a young fellow from Augusta named Carl Sanders who was going to run for governor and upstart senator across the hall and he was the underdog but Murphy believed in him and he got behind Carl Sanders and lo and behold Carl Sanders got elected governor in 1962 well another bit of history about this house that many people don't understand is that this house has always not been an independent body we did not always choose our speaker we did not always have our own say of who chairman of the committees were the governor did all that in 1962 he ran this place it's another story about how we got our independence but at that time because Tom Murphy had backed the governor he made him the chairman of the committee which was unheard of back then for a sophomore to be chairman of a committee in the house and the governor allowed him to do that and one day during that next session the governor got word down on the second floor that Tom Murphy one of his chairman was out here on the floor working against one of the governor's bills well the governor called Tom Murphy down to his office and asked him he said Tom what is this out here he said I so much appreciate you supporting me and getting behind me I made you as a sophomore to the chairman of one of my committees in the house and you're down there working against my bill on the floor you just can't do that and Murphy doodifully listen to his governor and went back to the floor of the house and went right back to working against the governor's bill well governor got word of that called Murphy back to his office and fired him on the spot his chairman of one of his committees it was an unheard of thing right in the middle of session fire one of the chairman well the next morning rode around and who came to the well of this house Tom Murphy he stood right here in this spot they said you could have heard a pin drop on the floor of the house he came to this well and he said it comes a time and a place in every man's life when he's got to stand up and say what he believes and he said right now is neither the time nor the place to do that and then he announced a charity basketball game they were going to have that after that the first time I ever met speaker Murphy was in 1986 I was a young intern Dr. Charles Bullock over at the University of Georgia I took his Southern politics class and he let me even before I took his legislative process class do something that any political science kid that wants to go to law school would love to do is come maybe an intern in the legislature and lo and behold I got the plum committee I got to be the intern for the House Judiciary Committee in 1986 and my specialist the thing I was most good at down in the House Judiciary Committee was the three C's I got coffee I got coke and I got copies and I could fix you up if you needed that well if y'all have been down to that judiciary committee I know you have it was even more busy back then because it was really only one judiciary committee in the House back then in Murphy being on a lawyer speaker Murphy that's where he sent everything and particularly things he wanted worked on and the big issue the big issue lo and behold in 1986 was something called tort reform and there were three members very prominent members of that committee in this House who had introduced a tort reform bill to reform the legal system one of them was an upstart young fellow named Pete Robinson from over in Columbus George he had a little company a new company is district called Affleck and of course Pete went on to be the majority leader in the Senate head of Troutman Sanders government affairs department a great fellow but he introduced a tort reform bill in 1986 his number two son was a guy named Tommy Chameless he was vice chairman of the Judiciary Committee Tommy had a little entity entity down in his district and all make all Phoebe Putney hospital and and he was the number two son of the vice chairman the third son are on that now was a guy named Denmark Groover Denny Groover they used to say for years down here if you want to bill right you give it to Denny and he Grooverize it he was the whip of the House he sent right there in that spot he was Tom Murphy's lawyer and he was the number three son are on that bill the whip of the House well it came today for the for the for the first big committee or or so and of course I'm down there that Judiciary Room was packed full of people and we've been down there at about four or five hours of hearings you know how things go down there and all of a sudden the chairman of the committee Charles Thomas from over in Temple Georgia on that near Bremen he grew up knowing the speaker he did this right here to me me I mean intern I kneel down now this is before cell phones and taxes and everything like that he kneeled down I kneel down and he said to me you and only you go to the speaker's office and you tell the speaker and only the speaker things are not going right and he needs to come down here now I said you want me to go to the speaker's office and telling that he said you and only you and don't you talk to anybody else I said where's the speaker's office he said third floor ask anybody so you know here I go I come up here and I find the speaker's office and I walk in now back in those days you did not get to see the speaker unless you got through Lunele Lunele was a speaker secretary and she was the gatekeeper so I walk in the door and she says young man cannot help you and I said yes ma'am I need to see the speaker she said well who are you I said I'm very flimmy she says well what do you do I says I'm the intern for the House Judiciary Committee she said that's fine so just tell me what you need and I'll take care of it I said no ma'am chairman Thomas said I could only speak to the speaker she said okay so she then brought me back to the chief of staff's office a guy named Steve Anthony ended up being a law professor over at Georgia State and I walked into the chief of staff's office he said young man can I help you I said yes sir I need to see the speaker he said well who are you I said I'm very flimmy he said well what do you do I said I'm the intern for the House Judiciary Committee he said well son just tell me what you need and I'll take care of it I said no sir the chairman said I could only speak to the speaker he said all right so I'm gonna hold on just a minute second later too he walks me into speaker Murphy's office first time I ever met him in my life he said son who are you I said I'm very flimmin he said what do you do here I said I'm the intern for the House Judiciary Committee he said son what do you need I said mr. Speaker the chairman told me to come tell you that things are not going right without bill and you need to come down there now he said all right son you go back down there and you sit down and you don't say nothing to nobody so I made my way back down to the judiciary committee I went by the refrigerator and got a coke for good fashion set it up there in front of the chairman setting my little position over there in the corner after 30 seconds chairman looked over at me and I said about a minute or two later that door swung open back there in judiciary and and him walk speaker Murphy now that room was packed the fire marshal would have arrested everybody in there but it looked like Moses part in the Red Sea when speaker Murphy walked up to that judiciary table in the chairman stopped the meeting right there and said well my goodness mr. Speaker what in the world brings you down here today and speaker Murphy walked over to the table like he could he's the larger than life figure a big man he said well I'm sorry mr. chairman to come down hand interrupt your proceedings I know y'all got a lot of stuff going on but I just wanted to come down hand tell y'all how much I appreciate what y'all are doing he says I know I send you too many bills down here you're down here every day all day it's running your law practice but I could not run this house if it were not for y'all and I just wanted to come and say thank you and he turned to walk away and then he leaned back and he says in the worst the worst bill I've ever seen in my life you get Pete Robinson to tell you that story back when he was still here and he'll tell you they had about 14 15 16 votes out of the 20 or so lawyers on that committee and after the speaker Murphy left it went back to the three guys who signed the bill mr. Speaker that's one I learned about the procedure of the house of representatives procedure rule number one the speaker is always right house procedure rule number two went in doubt refer to rule number one I'll end this morning by probably doing the more important thing and that is thanking my family for allowing me to come down here and serve I knew they were going to be here this afternoon for the the swearing in but I did not know that they were going to get to be here this morning my beautiful wife Paige and my son I love Zach are both back there in the back and my brother Jimmy is I stand before you today to discuss a significant policy change within the Veterans Administration that's far reaching implications for nation's heroes. Beginning one week from today, January 17th, all eligible veterans will be able to access emergency mental health care free of charge at any Veterans Medical Facility or outside clinic. This is regardless of whether they are already enrolled in the Department of Health Care Services. This marks a crucial step for in ensuring the well-being of our veterans, particularly in their most acute times of need. Under Section 201, the VA commits to providing or paying for treatment of eligible individuals in emergent suicidal care, including transportation costs, added to a VA or non-VA facility, this extends 30 days of inpatient care and 90 days of outpatient care with possibility of an extension. Additionally, appropriate referrals to continued care and eligibility. So who's eligible? There are some further caveats, but veterans who served before September 1980 who were discharged under conditions that were not dishonorable. Veterans who joined after September 7th, 1980 who have served 24 months, also not discharged other than dishonorable. And I invite any colleagues who are interested in the issue of maternal mortality to join me here at the well. So this morning colleagues, like many of you, I attended eggs and issues sponsored by the Georgia Chamber of Commerce, I am so pleased to hear that health care is among their priorities. And I was so encouraged to hear that it is a priority of this house, this session, to increase access to health care and provide better outcomes for Georgia families. Georgia's mothers desperately need better outcomes. The House Democratic Caucus held a hearing on maternal mortality last week. I had the great privilege of sitting on that committee. Many groups who dedicate themselves to this issue testified before the committee. They were professionals, doctors, nurses, academics, organizers. And we also heard directly from women who either had had a near-death experience during childbirth or lost someone they loved during childbirth. And woman after woman shared their souls with us. They're most painful moments in the hopes that we can do something to change maternal outcomes for our fellow Georgians. I had a harrowing experience the first time I gave birth. If my good friend who happened to be an OB nurse hadn't advocated for me, I don't know what would have happened. And my guess is that every one of us in this chamber has either had such an experience personally or knows someone who has had such an experience or has lost someone they loved during childbirth. Because even though having a child is a natural thing, it is also an extremely dangerous thing. I have three kids. As a mom, I remember kissing my children as I went to go give birth at the hospital. And it was this crazy conflation of feelings, this excitement that I was going to bring a new life into the world into my home. But also a fear that if God forbid something should happen to me during childbirth, I would not see my children on this earth again. And the truth is that that fear, that risk, it's higher for my black sisters. Black women in Georgia are 3.3 times more likely to die from pregnancy-related complications than white women are. Georgia has one of the worst maternal mortality rates in the country. Third highest in the country. And by the way, it's getting worse, not better. I used to refer to the death of women during childbirth in Georgia as a crisis, the maternal mortality crisis. But after last week's hearing, I'm going to adopt new nomenclature that I think more accurately describes what is happening here in Georgia. It is a state of emergency. Women and babies are dying. Black women and black babies are dying. These are tragedies that do not have to happen. Over half of them are preventable. And so this is a call for action. We will continue beating this drum. Colleagues, I invite you all to join us. Let's pass some legislation and save precious lives. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I yield the well. Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker. We rise before you today with heavy hearts. A former member of this body, Roy H. Sonny Watson, went to be with the Lord yesterday, January 9th, 2024. Somebody who was larger than life and want appropriately acknowledged and honor him with a couple of things that were written. He grew up in what is now known as one of Robbins. He graduated from Georgia Military College and then later earned his degree at Mercer University. He humbly began his career at a fillin station and then he became the city clerk and administrative for Houston County and served in that capacity for 17 years before he was elected to this body where he served a distinguished career for 22 years and he earned the title as you heard earlier, The Chairman. I think you'll hear more about that from Chairman Powell but he served as the House Industry Committee Chairman and frankly rewrote the book on how to serve in that capacity. I think one of the most notable things he shepherded through this body was what is one of the most successful programs in Georgia's history and that's the Hope Scholarship program. Of course, he didn't stop when he left this body and went back home. He was a brilliant and successful business person with Watson Insurance Agency. He served as the chair of the Houston County Healthcare System for 18 years and he was a champion of so many things, one of Robbins, middle Georgia Technical College Robbins Air Force Base, Museum of Aviation, and I could go on. I think he was fair to say that he was tough but compassionate. I don't think I ever visited his office when I didn't leave having left numerous times and learned something very profound. He was highly respected, much admired.

and people loved him. Hope you'll join me in praying God's peace over his wife of 67 years. Janine, his daughter Cindy, his grandchildren Jennifer and Joseph. Members of the house, a lot of y'all have heard me talk about this over the years and those of us who have a certain number of years of historical perspective. We talk about this that we're all a, we're all colleagues, whether you're here or whether you're gone, but we're all brothers and sisters. We serve in the greatest fraternity that there's ever been. I was fortunate enough when I was elected 34 years ago and took office to speak of Murphy and those people in power at that time saw something and they assigned me to Sonny Watson's to-lige. Now, what my friend from Warner Robin said about compassion, I never saw that in Sonny while he served. I'm obviously when he left public service here, that society came out of it. But he absolutely wrote the book on how to be a chairman. And a lot of y'all who crinkle your eyes up, it made some things that I say, well, you can blame it on Sonny Watson. Because Sonny taught me how to be a chairman. One of the things that people don't realize about Sonny Watson, and they remember Zell Miller, they remember the lottery, but a lot of people don't remember that one. Zell was elected. It was still the lottery barely passed. At that time, we had all the old felt hat crowd from World War II and the Korean War. And those guys at that time were absolutely petrified to vote on gambling or petrified to vote on alcohol issues. But Sonny Watson never blinked to eye. When that bill came to the committee, we dispatched it. And if it had not been for Sonny Watson, then that program today would not be an effect. He was absolutely a chairman, chairman. In that day and time, the house had probably half as many chairs as they do now. Being a chairman, absolutely meant you had to be a chairman, very sought after committee. Sonny sat right over here on this side over here, on the front row. And with Sonny, if you asked a question, you'd have to have to worry about where he stood on things. If something went to the committee, it was all about business at that point. So that being said, I would admonish every member in this house to think about this, that you could be fortunate enough when your tour comes to an end in this house chamber, the people's house. That if your memory is still there, and you've passed on certain information to other members, it'll carry forward and you will be as lucky as Sonny Watson has been that he has has revered. And you don't have to believe me. There's still a few lobbyists around that he can probably testify to that. I would tell you plenty of stories as his vice chairman for several years, some of the things that he had said, but I will give you one, the cleaner version. He was so good at the legislative process that I saw something done under his chairmanship, I'd never seen done. There was a lobbyist that made fun one day to their dismay that a certain piece of legislation never was dropped in or passed. And he was making fun of it. And he made the mistake of quoting that, well, chairman Watson didn't get his way this time. Sonny had a bill drafted within 30 minutes. And of course, we did things different in that day. Drop the bill in, had the rules suspended, hadn't read, had it assigned. We had a committee meeting in the aneurium of the industry committee, bill Lee called a meeting of the rules committee in the same fashion. And within an hour that bill was on the floor passed and in the Senate. And Sonny walked outside and that lobbyist was still cackling about the fact that that bill hadn't ever got any further. And he told him, he says, you need to go to the Senate. And that bill did pass. But that is a man who was committed to this house. He was committed to the independence of this house. He didn't shy away from Speaker Murphy when the speaker was wrong, nor any governor. So that being said is just a history about a great man who served in this house for a number of years.
